diode-th.name: Through-Hole Diodes (1N4148)
pros: Can be bent to fit various PCB layouts

diode-smd.name: SMD Diodes (1N4148W SOD-123)
cons: Harder to solder (requires fine tip and steady hand)
Polarity harder to see (look for line marking)
Difficult to rework if placed incorrectly

trrs-jack.name: TRRS Jack (PJ-320A)
pros: Carries VCC, GND, and 2 data lines
cons: Can short if plugged/unplugged while powered
trrs-jack.warning: Always use TRRS (4-conductor) cables, not TRS (3-conductor) to avoid shorts

trs-jack.name: TRS Jack (3-conductor)
pros: Less chance of incorrect cable usage
usedFor: Connecting split keyboard halves with serial only
trs-jack.note: TRRS is generally preferred as it supports more communication protocols

usb-c-connector.name: USB-C Connector (Mid-Mount)
pros: Reversible (no wrong way to plug in)
cons: Need proper CC resistors (5.1kΩ) for compatibility
usedFor: Direct USB connection to computer (without Pro Micro)
usb-c-connector.note: Requires 5.1kΩ pull-down resistors on CC1 and CC2 pins for USB-C specification compliance

micro-usb-connector.name: Micro-USB Connector (Breakout)
cons: Not reversible (can plug in wrong way)
micro-usb-connector.note: USB-C is recommended for new designs

reset-button.name: Reset Button (Tactile Switch)
pros: Can be mounted on case or PCB
cons: Need case cutout if accessible externally
usedFor: Resetting microcontroller, entering bootloader for firmware flashing
reset-button.note: Almost essential for easy firmware updates

boot-button.name: Boot/Flash Button
cons: Not strictly necessary (can use key combo)
usedFor: Entering bootloader mode for firmware flashing (RP2040, etc.)

power-switch-slide.name: Power Switch (Slide Switch)
pros: Prevents battery drain when not in use
cons: Can be fragile if mounted on PCB edge
usedFor: Turning wireless keyboards on/off to save battery

battery-connector-jst.name: Battery Connector (JST-PH 2.0mm)
usedFor: Connecting LiPo battery to wireless keyboard

speaker-passive.name: Passive Buzzer/Speaker
pros: Can indicate layer changes, errors, etc.

capacitor-ceramic.name: Ceramic Capacitors (0.1µF, 10µF)
pros: Prevents MCU crashes from power spikes
capacitor-ceramic.note: Typically use 0.1µF near each IC power pin, 10µF at power input

esd-protection.name: ESD Protection Diode (USBLC6-2SC6)
pros: Protects USB data lines from static discharge
cons: Not strictly necessary for basic builds
usedFor: Protecting USB data lines from ESD damage
esd-protection.note: Optional but recommended for professional builds, especially with exposed USB connectors

polyfuse.name: Polyfuse (Resettable Fuse)
cons: Can limit peak current for RGB/power-hungry features
polyfuse.note: Place in series with USB VBUS - highly recommended for safety

schottky-diode.name: Schottky Diode (BAT85, 1N5819)
pros: Essential for wireless builds with USB charging
schottky-diode.note: Use between battery and power rail to prevent USB from charging battery unsafely

voltage-regulator.name: Voltage Regulator (AMS1117-3.3V)
pros: Simple to use with input/output caps
cons: Not needed if MCU provides 3.3V output
Linear regulators waste power as heat
voltage-regulator.note: Only needed if using 3.3V-only components like some OLEDs or sensors

io-expander.name: I2C IO Expander (MCP23017)
pros: Allows larger matrices without extra MCU pins
usedFor: Expanding key matrix beyond MCU pin count
io-expander.note: Advanced option - only needed for very large keyboards (80+ keys) on pin-limited MCUs

ws2812b-led.name: WS2812B RGB LED (Individual)
pros: Only uses 1 data pin for entire chain
cons: High power draw (60mA each at full white)
Can be finicky with data signal
Adds significant cost for full board
ws2812b-led.note: Often used in strips for underglow. Per-key RGB for 60 keys = $9 + power concerns

sk6812-mini.name: SK6812 Mini RGB LED
sk6812-mini.note: Harder to solder but cleaner integration. Consider WS2812B for first RGB build

choc-v2.name: Kailh Choc v2
cons: Less common than v1 or MX

hotswap.name: Hot-Swap Sockets
hotswap.description: Install sockets to swap switches without soldering
cons: Potential for socket failure over time

rgb.name: RGB LED Backlighting
rgb.description: Per-key RGB lighting using WS2812B or SK6812 LEDs

oled.name: OLED Display
oled.description: 128x32 or 128x64 OLED screen for status display

encoder.name: Rotary Encoder (EC11/EC12)
encoder.description: Rotary knob for volume, scrolling, etc. Standard EC11 or EC12 type with optional push button
pros: Push button adds extra key functionality
Can control brightness, zoom, timeline scrubbing

encoder-evqwgd001.name: EVQWGD001 Encoder (Low Profile)
encoder-evqwgd001.description: Ultra low-profile encoder, ideal for thin keyboards. Used in high-end products like Apple Magic Keyboard

trackball.name: Integrated Trackball (PMW3360)
trackball.description: PMW3360 optical sensor with trackball bearing system for precision mouse control
trackball.note: Requires 3D-printed trackball housing and ceramic/ruby bearings

trackball-adns9800.name: Budget Trackball (ADNS-9800)
trackball-adns9800.description: Lower-cost optical sensor option for trackball integration

trackpoint.name: TrackPoint Pointing Stick
trackpoint.description: IBM-style pointing stick (the red nub). Pressure-sensitive isometric joystick for cursor control
cons: Sourcing genuine modules can be expensive
trackpoint.note: Can salvage from old ThinkPad keyboards or buy clone modules

cirque-trackpad.name: Cirque Trackpad (Mini)
cirque-trackpad.description: Small circular trackpad module. Multi-touch capable with excellent QMK support
pros: No mechanical parts to wear out
cons: Less precise than trackball for some users
cirque-trackpad.note: This is the 'mini circle mouse pad thing' - very popular in custom keyboards

analog-thumbstick.name: Analog Thumb Joystick
analog-thumbstick.description: PlayStation/Xbox-style analog thumbstick for gaming keyboards. Dual-axis analog input
pros: Great for WASD replacement in games
Fun for creative workflows (brush size, zoom)
cons: Not all MCUs have enough ADC pins
Firmware support varies (QMK analog support improving)
Joystick caps can break over time
analog-thumbstick.note: Requires controller with ADC pins (RP2040 has 4, Pro Micro has 4)

trrs.name: TRRS Cable (Wired)
trrs.description: 3.5mm TRRS cable for wired split connection using serial communication

usbc-wired.name: USB-C Cable (Wired)
usbc-wired.description: USB-C cable for wired split connection using serial communication over D+/D- lines
pros: Can be hot-pluggable with proper firmware
cons: Requires USB-C breakout or connector soldering
Not true USB protocol (uses serial over USB pins)

wire-26awg-solid.name: 26AWG Solid-Core Wire
cons: Not good for areas with movement

wire-28awg-magnet.name: 28AWG Magnet Wire
pros: Very thin - fits in tight spaces

solder-leaded.name: Leaded Solder (63/37, 0.8mm)
cons: Being phased out in some regions

desoldering-braid.name: Desoldering Braid/Wick
cons: Need to cut off used sections

heat-shrink-kit.name: Heat Shrink Tubing Kit
pros: Easy to use with heat gun or lighter

pin-headers.name: Pin Headers (Male/Female)
cons: Not as secure as direct solder

millmax-sockets.name: Mill-Max Hot-Swap Sockets
cons: Can be pushed out if not careful

qmk.name: QMK Firmware
qmk.description: Open-source keyboard firmware with extensive features

vial.name: Vial (QMK + GUI)
vial.description: QMK fork with real-time GUI configuration

kmk.name: KMK Firmware
cons: Slightly higher latency than compiled firmware

zmk.name: ZMK Firmware
zmk.description: Modern firmware designed for wireless keyboards
